text: A surprisingly large number of freak hailstorms

wreak havoc on shopping malls. 
And that’s not a coincidence.
Welcome to MinuteEarth.

Big malls - and their even bigger parking lots 
- are basically just giant slabs of concrete

and asphalt that absorb the sun’s energy and 
radiate that heat back out, which can raise

the temperature at a mega-mall by several degrees. 
That warm air rises, pushing up the top-most layer

of the clouds, known as the “tropopause.” 
Meanwhile, the trees and grass that often

border malls create shade and, through evaporative 
cooling, keep the surface temperature there cool,

so the surrounding tropopause stays low and traps 
the rising air in a narrow column. As the column

of air gets taller, the moisture in the clouds 
starts to condense, forming water droplets. At the

same time, the volume of that column increases, 
creating a low-pressure vacuum effect that pulls

air molecules towards the center, causing wind. In 
other words, it creates the perfect conditions for

a storm to form. And the hotter the temperature 
on the ground, the quicker and higher the storm

cloud rises into the frigid air above, increasing 
the likelihood that the water in it freezes into

ice balls. The result: concentrated, destructive 
hailstorms focused directly over shopping malls.

It’s not just malls, of course; any big 
difference in neighboring surface temperatures

can trigger extreme weather. Mega-cities 
- known as heat islands - get up to 50%

more rain than the tree-lined ‘burbs. And 
sun-baked farm fields cut into the forest

are more likely to experience thunderstorms 
and tornadoes than the forests themselves.

Luckily, through simple actions like planting 
trees in parking lots and sidewalks and farm

fields for shade and evaporative cooling - 
or even painting some of those areas white

so they don’t soak up as much heat - we can 
keep surface temperatures more uniform and

limit destructive conditions from forming in the 
first place. Otherwise, there will be hail to pay.

Trees and grasses aren’t just good at cooling our 
micro-environments; they can also help keep our

entire globe cool by sucking up planet-warming 
carbon dioxide. And now, you too can help suck

up carbon dioxide. With a little information 
about your habits and lifestyle, our sponsor Wren

calculates your current carbon footprint and makes 
all sorts of suggestions about how to reduce it.

Wren also allows you to offset the carbon that 
you do release by making a monthly contribution

towards projects like this one, which turns

fertilizer. And for each of the first 100 of you
